metadata.product: Gabrylly Ergonomic Mesh Office Chair, High Back Desk Chair

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** David

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Tatum ---

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Hi Tatum, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is David, and I’m a representative from Gabrylly. We really appreciate you agreeing to this call, especially after your recent experience with our ergonomic mesh office chair. We take all feedback very seriously, particularly when it's as candid as yours, and we're genuinely here to understand your perspective better so we can improve.

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Yeah, no problem, David. Uh, happy to talk about it. Honestly, I'm just glad someone's actually listening now. It's been, well, quite the ordeal.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I completely understand, and I want to assure you that your feedback is invaluable to us. We’ve reviewed your detailed feedback on Amazon, and I truly apologize for the frustrating experience you've had. To start, could you tell me a little bit more about what initially prompted you to look for a new office chair? What were you hoping to achieve with this purchase?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Well, like I said in the review, I do a fair bit of freelance writing on the side, you know, on top of my regular admin job. And I’d just been using this old dining room chair, honestly, for ages. It was… not cutting it. My back was constantly aching, and, uh, I just figured, you know, if I’m spending hours at my desk, I need something proper, something supportive. I really wanted to invest in my home office setup, something that would last and actually help my posture, not hurt it.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. Investing in a good chair for extended work hours is crucial for comfort and health. And when you were looking, what specifically about the Gabrylly chair caught your eye? What made you choose us over other options you might have been considering?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Hmm, good question. I spent a fair bit of time on Amazon, just scrolling through, comparing. Your chair, the Gabrylly one, it had a lot of reviews, mostly positive, which, you know, now I question the authenticity of some of them. But at the time, it looked… sleek. It had that modern mesh design, which I thought would be good for breathability – San Francisco can get surprisingly warm, even indoors, sometimes. And the price point, it felt like a mid-range option. Not super cheap, not ridiculously expensive. I figured I was getting a good balance of features for the cost. I looked at a few others, but this one just seemed like a solid choice for what I thought was good value.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I see. So, the aesthetics, the mesh for breathability, and what seemed like a good value proposition were key factors. You mentioned in your review that the first sign of trouble was during assembly. Could you walk me through that a bit more? What exactly happened with the bolts and the instructions?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Oh, boy. The assembly. Yeah. I'm usually pretty good with this stuff. I’ve put together countless IKEA flat-packs, even built some shelves from scratch. So, I’m not, like, completely incompetent. But with this chair, it was a mess from the start. I opened the box, dumped everything out, and right away noticed something was off. Several of the bolts, they just weren’t there, or they were… stripped. Like, the threading was already messed up before I even tried to put them in.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Stripped *before* you even started tightening them? That's certainly not what we want our customers to experience.

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Exactly! It was infuriating. And then the instructions… ugh. They were so sparse. Just a few poorly translated diagrams. I remember trying to match parts, squinting at these tiny drawings. It felt like a puzzle, but a really frustrating one, not a fun one. I ended up having to dig through my own hardware stash to find replacement bolts that would actually fit and tighten. And even then, one of the armrests, no matter what I did, it just wouldn't get properly secure. It's still wobbly.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's incredibly frustrating, Tatum. Having to source your own parts and dealing with a wobbly component right out of the gate completely undermines the initial experience. You also mentioned the materials felt cheap, especially the metal and threading for critical components. Could you elaborate on what specifically gave you that impression?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Yeah, definitely. It was mainly the armrest, that's where I first noticed it. When I was trying to tighten it, it just felt like the metal, or whatever alloy they used, was incredibly soft. It just… gave way. Like it couldn't hold the tension. And the threading, it just felt shallow. Not a solid, deep thread that would really grip. It made me immediately worry about the longevity of the whole thing, you know? If the basic connection points are that flimsy, what about the rest? It just felt like corners were cut wherever possible.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I appreciate you detailing that. It helps us understand the quality concerns. Moving on from assembly, you wrote quite a bit about the comfort, or lack thereof, once the chair was put together. You specifically mentioned the mesh seat feeling like a "trampoline stretched too tight" and the frame being felt. Can you expand on how that impacted your daily use?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Oh, the seat. That was probably the most immediate ergonomic nightmare. I sat down, and it was just… hard. Like sitting on a board with a thin layer of mesh over it. After just, I don't know, an hour or two of sitting, my glutes and hamstrings were screaming. Literally. There’s no cushioning *at all*. And if I shifted even slightly, I could feel the hard plastic or metal frame underneath the mesh, especially right where my thighs would meet the back of the seat. It’s supposed to be "high-density" mesh, but it felt more like "high-tension, low-comfort" mesh.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** So, the intended support and comfort from the mesh were completely absent, and it actually caused discomfort. You tried adding a gel cushion – what was the outcome of that?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** I did! I went out and bought a decent gel cushion, thinking, "Okay, this will solve it." And it did help with the direct pressure on my butt, sure. But then, it raised me up too high. So my feet weren't flat on the floor anymore, and the headrest, which I occasionally used, was completely out of position. And the armrests? They were now too low to be useful. So, it totally defeated the purpose of having an adjustable, ergonomic chair. Plus, part of the appeal of mesh was the breathability, and putting a cushion on it, you know, negates that. It was just a lose-lose situation.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** It sounds like a cascade of issues, where one fix simply created another problem. You also highlighted the lumbar support as a "joke." Could you describe where it hit your back and why it wasn't effective for you?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** "Joke" is being kind, honestly. It's just a stiff, non-adjustable hump that pushes into my mid-back. Not my lower back, where I actually *need* lumbar support. I’m an administrator, David, I know what good lumbar support feels like from my office chairs at work. This felt like it was designed to *create* a back problem, not alleviate one. It pushed me forward in an awkward way, forcing my spine into an unnatural curve. It’s honestly worse than having no lumbar support at all.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's a critical piece of feedback. Lumbar support is meant to align with the natural curve of the lower spine, and it sounds like this was completely off for your anatomy. But the most significant issue you reported, and I understand this is a major one, was the hydraulic cylinder failing. Can you tell me more about when that started and how it progressed?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Oh, the cylinder. That's the absolute worst part. After less than a month of use, I noticed it. I'd set it to my preferred height, get comfortable, and then, slowly but surely, I’d start sinking. At first, it was subtle, just a little bit. But then, it got worse. A lot worse. Within 15-20 minutes, I’d be several inches lower, practically slouching under my desk, trying to type. It was incredibly disruptive.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** And how did that impact your ability to work, especially with your freelance writing?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** It was a complete productivity killer! I mean, I’m trying to focus, get into a flow, and suddenly I’m fighting with my chair. My posture was terrible, my wrists were at an odd angle to the keyboard, my neck was craning to see the monitor properly. It just created this constant tension and distraction. It wasn't just an inconvenience; it genuinely felt like a serious ergonomic hazard. I was worried it was doing permanent damage to my back and neck. And for a chair that was supposed to be *ergonomic*? It’s just unacceptable.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I completely agree, that's not the experience we intend for our users. You mentioned reaching out to customer service through Amazon. Could you describe that interaction? You said you waited a week for responses, provided photos and videos…

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Yeah, so after a few weeks of dealing with the sinking, I finally had enough. I went through Amazon’s messaging system. It was a week of back and forth, just what I didn't need. They kept asking for photos, videos, more details. I sent them everything they asked for – videos of me sitting in the chair and slowly sinking, pictures of the cylinder, the wobbly armrest, everything. It felt like they were trying to wear me down.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** It sounds like a lot of hoops to jump through. And then they offered a replacement cylinder?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Eventually, yes. After all that, they said they'd send a replacement cylinder. That was two weeks ago. And nothing. Absolutely nothing. I followed up, and I just got this generic email about "shipping delays." I mean, I understand things happen, but after everything else, it just feels like a brush-off. It’s like they don’t care once they have your money. For a chair that cost me, you know, a few hundred dollars, I expected a minimum level of quality, and certainly, *much* better customer support. This is just… beyond frustrating.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I hear your frustration, Tatum, and I want to apologize on behalf of Gabrylly for that experience with our customer service team. That's not the standard we aim for, and the lack of follow-through is unacceptable. Reflecting on your entire experience, from purchase to present day, what would you say was the biggest disappointment, if you had to pick just one thing?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Oh, just one thing? That’s hard, there’s so much wrong. Uhm… I think the biggest disappointment is the complete failure of the *core function* of an office chair. It’s supposed to support you at a consistent height, comfortably. This chair failed on both counts. The sinking cylinder combined with the agonizing seat… it made working impossible. It turned an investment into a liability. I mean, the customer service was awful, but that’s secondary to the product itself being fundamentally flawed and unusable.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's a very clear point. And looking at the flip side, was there *anything* about the chair that met or even slightly exceeded your expectations, however small?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** (Pauses, thinks) Uhm… honestly, not really in terms of function or comfort. I guess the *look* of it is still sleek, as I initially thought. It fits well visually in my small home office space. It *looks* like a modern ergonomic chair. But that's purely cosmetic, you know? It’s like buying a fancy car that doesn’t start. So, no, not really anything that exceeded expectations once I actually started using it. My expectations were pretty basic, just for it to work as advertised.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I appreciate your honesty. If you were to give us specific suggestions for improving this chair, based on your experience, what would be the top two or three things you'd tell our product development team to focus on?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Okay, definitely: 1.  **Quality Control, especially assembly components:** You *have* to make sure all the parts are in the box and that the bolts aren't stripped. And better quality threading for critical components, like the armrests. This shouldn't be a DIY project where I have to supply my own hardware. 2.  **The Seat:** This is huge. It needs actual padding, or a much more forgiving mesh, and definitely redesign the frame underneath so it’s not digging into people's legs. It's just not fit for purpose for anyone sitting for more than an hour. 3.  **The Hydraulic Cylinder:** This is non-negotiable. It has to be reliable. If it can't hold height, the chair is useless. Invest in a better quality cylinder, period. And then, as a bonus, the lumbar support needs to be adjustable and actually hit the lower back. The current design is just… wrong.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Those are very clear and actionable points, Tatum, thank you. You mentioned this chair cost "this much." Could you share your general price perception now, given your experience? Do you feel you got any value for your money?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** No, absolutely not. I paid, I think, around two hundred and fifty dollars for it. Maybe a little more, I can’t remember exactly. But for that price, I expected a functional, comfortable chair that would last more than a month. What I got was an expensive piece of junk that caused me physical pain and stress. It feels like a total scam, frankly. I’d say it's worth maybe fifty bucks, if that, just for the parts I could scavenge. So, zero value for my money. It was a complete waste.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Understanding that, how likely would you be to recommend the Gabrylly Ergonomic Mesh Office Chair to a friend or colleague, on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 is "definitely not" and 10 is "absolutely"?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** (Laughs, a short, humorless sound) Oh, David. A zero. A hard zero. I would actively warn people *against* buying it. I mean, between the assembly nightmare, the pain it caused me, and the completely unhelpful customer service… why would I recommend something like that to anyone I care about? I wouldn’t wish this experience on my worst enemy.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Thank you for that candid response. And as a final question, looking forward, what would be the absolute critical features or qualities you would seek out in your *next* office chair? What would make you feel confident in investing in a different brand or model?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Reliability, above all else. I need to know the components are going to work and last. And comfort. Real, actual comfort for extended sitting, with proper cushioning and adjustable, effective lumbar support. I think I’d prioritize reviews that specifically mention long-term comfort and durability, even if it means paying a bit more. And I'd probably look for a brand with a reputation for solid customer service, just in case something does go wrong. I need something that *helps* my work, not hinders it. I'm actually already looking at some local office supply stores, where I can physically try out chairs before buying them, instead of relying solely on online reviews.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Tatum, this has been incredibly detailed and helpful. Your insights are genuinely important to us as we work to improve our products and our customer experience. We truly regret that your experience with Gabrylly has been so poor, and I want to personally thank you for being so open and honest with your feedback. We will be taking everything you’ve shared back to our teams. Before we wrap up, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being extremely dissatisfied and 10 being extremely satisfied, how would you rate your overall satisfaction with your experience with Gabrylly and this product?

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Well, just with this product and the company as a whole, considering everything? It’s a 1, David. Maybe a 0, but I’ll give you a 1 because you at least called. But the product itself? Definitely a 1.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Thank you, Tatum. I understand that rating, and again, I sincerely apologize. We appreciate your time and candor today. We will be in touch regarding your specific customer service case to ensure we address the replacement cylinder situation.

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** Okay, I appreciate that. Thanks for listening.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Thank you, Tatum. Have a good day.

transcript.speaker: **Tatum
transcript.text: ** You too. ---
